subject: History
title: Spies in No Man's Land
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Spies in No Man's Land.

hook.text: Trench warfare created a bizarre espionage landscape where enemy lines were sometimes just 30 meters apart.

buildup.text: Soldiers tunneled under trenches to plant listening devices and eavesdrop on enemy conversations.

discovery.text: Both sides used carrier pigeons for messages. Counter-intelligence trained hawks to intercept them mid-flight.

twist.text: A British soldier named Henry Tandey spared a wounded German soldier in 1918. That soldier was Adolf Hitler.

climax.text: The Western Front proved that intelligence without mobility is useless. Knowing enemy plans didn't break the stalemate.

punchline.text: They could hear the enemy but couldn't reach them.

quiz.question: How did armies counter enemy carrier pigeons during WWI?
